attributes.subtitle: Building a Complete Social Network
attributes.description: Creating real connections using cutting-edge technology

content.body:
# About Olimaps
The project Olimaps aims to analyze a company that provides video communication services, such as Zoom, in order to understand the relationship between the value of the company and the current health crisis. Olimaps also aims to address the opportunity for people to regain confidence in physical socialization and to use new technologies to meet their needs. The project was created in response to the growing need for people to recover physical relationships during the pandemic.

## ARCHITECTURE

In the architecture design we plan as the overall design of our platform from different points of view, each of the points of view will give us a different perspective of how the Olimaps architecture is composed.

### The logical view

This view represents the system from the perspective of the end user. It focuses on the functional requirements of the system and how the system appears to the user.

### The process view

This view represents the system from the perspective of the processes that execute within the system. It focuses on how the system performs work and how tasks are divided among the various components of the system.

### The development view

This view represents the development aspects of the system, including the tools and processes used to develop and maintain the system. It helps to ensure that the system is maintainable, extendable, and scalable over time.

### The physical view

This view represents the system from the perspective of the hardware and software components that make up the system. It focuses on the hardware and software infrastructure of the system and how the various components are connected and interact with each other.

### Use case view

This view represents the system from the perspective of the user interactions with the system. It focuses on the specific actions that users can perform with the system and how the system responds to those actions.

## PLANIFICATION

Design thinking is a creative approach to problem-solving that involves empathy for the users, a focus on their needs, and a rapid prototyping and iteration process. It is a holistic way of addressing challenges that takes into account the whole system in which the problem exists, rather than just its isolated parts. Design thinking can be applied to a wide range of fields, including software development, product design, and business strategy. The goal of design thinking is to come up with innovative solutions that are both functional and desirable for the users.

I begin by empathizing with the people I am designing for. This might involve conducting user research to gain insights into their needs and experiences.
Next, I define the problem I am trying to solve by synthesizing the insights I gathered in the empathize step and creating a specific, actionable problem statement.
Then, I generate ideas for potential solutions through brainstorming sessions or individual ideation exercises.
I build a physical or digital prototype of my ideas in order to test and iterate on them quickly and inexpensively.
5. Finally, I evaluate my prototypes with real users and gather feedback to inform further iteration and refinement.

Throughout this process, I focus on the needs of the users and the overall goal of the project, using the design thinking process to guide my decision-making and problem-solving.

In the context of design thinking, Scrum can be useful for gathering and incorporating user feedback because it provides a structured way to manage and prioritize feedback, as well as a regular cadence for reviewing and incorporating it into the product. For example, during each sprint, a Scrum team might conduct user research or usability testing to gather feedback on the product, and then use that feedback to inform the development work for the next sprint.

In this way, Scrum can help a team apply the principles of design thinking by providing a framework for continuously gathering and incorporating user feedback in order to iteratively improve the product over time.

For the task management of this project we have used GitHub as a way to centralise the process.

User stories are short, simple descriptions of a feature or functionality that a user would like to see in a product. They are often used in agile software development methodologies, such as Scrum, to capture the requirements of a project from the perspective of the end user.

Using user stories in GitHub can help your team track and manage the requirements of your project in a clear and organized way, and facilitate collaboration among team members.

## FRONTEND

Vue.js is a popular JavaScript framework for building user interfaces on the web. It's known for its simplicity and flexibility, and is often used for building single page applications (SPAs) - essentially, web pages that don't require a full page reload when navigating between different routes. This means that common elements between different pages can be preserved, making for a more seamless user experience.

Vue.js also allows for the creation of reactive components, which means that the visual elements of the page are automatically updated whenever the underlying data model changes. This can be especially useful in situations where the data being displayed is constantly changing, as it means the page will always be up-to-date without the need for manual refresh.

Nuxt.js is a meta-framework built on top of Vue.js that adds additional utilities and features. It's often used in professional projects where the codebase is expected to scale, as it comes with a number of tools and features that can help make the development process more efficient.

The Vuetify plugin is a set of pre-fabricated visual components that can be easily integrated into a Vue.js project. It's designed to help developers create layouts and designs that adhere to the guidelines of Material Design 2 - a set of design principles developed by Google - without having to spend a lot of time creating custom CSS.

The Mapbox API is a tool that allows developers to add interactive maps to their web applications. It provides a number of features, including the ability to customize the look and feel of the map, add markers and other data points, and allow users to interact with the map in various ways.

Service Workers are functions that can run in the background of a web application, even when the application itself is not actively being used. They can be used for tasks like listening for push notifications or performing other background tasks that need to be completed even when the application is not open.

As for the third party modules that we will be using, Firebase PUSH notifications and SMS are services that allow developers to send notifications and texts to users of their application. Google Analytics is a tool that allows developers to track and analyze user behavior on their web application.

To communicate with our backend, Axios is a library for making HTTP requests, which can be especially useful when building a RESTful service. Socket.io is a library that allows for bidirectional communication between a web application and a server, which can be useful for tasks like real-time messaging. Finally, passport.js is a tool that simplifies the authentication process by allowing developers to use various methods for verifying users.

## BACKEND

Our backend will act as a go-between for the frontend and the various services and databases we have. To do this, we will use Node.js, a popular environment for running JavaScript that's often used to implement web servers.

The frontend has multiple ways of connecting to the backend, depending on its needs. While each of these functions could have its own server, we've opted for a more monolithic design in order to avoid the added complexity of a microservices-based architecture. To handle HTTP requests from the frontend, we'll use Express.js, a library that makes it easy to develop servers using the REST protocol. While it was also an option to use GraphQL, we chose REST because it offers more flexibility and ease of development in case we need to scale to a microservices system.

For socket connections, we'll use the module on the server. This will allow us to keep track of the clients currently subscribed and ensure they're updated with notifications and messages in the chat. To manage authentication, we'll use Passport.js, a library that allows us to unify the authentication process and easily add new methods if needed. By default, it uses JWT tokens, which have the advantage of not requiring the server to store any client information.

To communicate with the database, we'll use an ORM (Object-Relational Mapping) called Prisma. This allows us to use object-oriented programming instead of SQL queries to interact with the database. Prisma uses TypeScript by default, which gives us the added benefits of an object-oriented and typed language when making database queries. This helps to improve organization and development in the project.

Additionally, we'll need to connect our server to a static file storage provider. To do this, we'll use the AWS.js library to communicate with our S3 storage service. Finally, we'll use Sendgrid to send emails to our users, mainly for account verification or password recovery.

## DATABASE

Designing our database was an important step in the development of our platform. To ensure we were able to manage large amounts of data and handle many interconnected queries, we looked to popular social media platforms like Twitter and Instagram for inspiration. These platforms often use a combination of relational and non-relational databases depending on their needs. Non-relational databases, also known as NoSQL databases, are typically used when a system needs to scale or when consultation times are a concern. On the other hand, relational databases are used when there are highly interconnected elements, like users and their posts.

Since our project is a minimum viable product and we are following an agile development methodology, we prioritized getting the project up and running quickly so we could get feedback from users. For this reason, we decided to use a single relational database to reduce complexity in our backend. However, as the number of active users increases, we may need to scale certain functionalities and will consider migration to a NoSQL database as a solution. To detect the need to scale, we will monitor our application and database for changes in loading times or potential errors.

We chose postgreSQL as our relational database because it is equipped to handle geolocated data. We also utilized the PostGIS extension to provide specialized data types and functions for spatial data. In addition to structured data storage, our platform needs a place to store static resources like images, videos, and audio files, as well as user profile images. To meet this need, we are using a cloud service like Amazon Web Services S3.

content.body:
# The Netflix of Fashion

Welcome to Pantala, where we're revolutionizing the way we consume fashion! Our company is dedicated to promoting circular economy, and we're excited to introduce you to our innovative clothing subscription service.

Picture having access to an unlimited closet of clothes that you can exchange monthly for three different pieces. Sounds too good to be true, right? Well, that's exactly what we're offering! Our mission is to give our customers the opportunity to enjoy a constantly evolving wardrobe, without the environmental impact that fast fashion can have.

We understand that the fashion industry has a significant impact on the environment, and that's why we have created a model that emphasizes garment reuse. Our unique system allows us to reuse the same garments among different customers, making our service not only eco-friendly but also cost-effective.

However, achieving this level of sustainability was not easy. Our team had to overcome technological challenges to ensure the seamless coordination of internal logistics and customer-facing interfaces. We also had to develop recommendation systems that would encourage our customers to embrace garment reuse.

At Pantala, we are committed to creating a sustainable and ethical fashion model that benefits both our customers and the planet. We invite you to join us in our mission to revolutionize the fashion industry, one garment at a time.

As a garment loan service, the garments return to our warehouse after use. Therefore, one of our objectives for cost optimization was to dispose of the garments we already had. This would reduce the number of new garments that needed to be purchased.

To perform this task, we had to take several factors into account:

- On the one hand in our inventory database we should have access to those garments that are currently in our warehouse.
- It is also important to take into account those garments that customers currently have, because there was a high probability that they would return to our warehouses.
- The history of garments that the user has owned
- The current fashion season

To make recommendations, we used a collaborative filtering algorithm that employed matrix factorization. This allowed us to suggest clothes that the user might like, based on the preferences of other users with similar tastes.

This gave us an ordered list of garments based on how much interest they might have for the user. We prioritized garments that were currently in stock, followed by those that could be restocked in time for the order. Garments that were not in stock were rejected outright.

This system made it easier for the user to find garments of interest while minimizing our costs.

### Minifying
During the build process we eliminate all unnecessary and redundant elements in our code to reduce the bundle size.

### Dynamic import
There are certain components in our platform that are not shown if the user does not make a previous interaction, such as dialogs or modals. In these cases, we decided to import these components at the moment the user interacts with them, so that only what is needed on the first page load is loaded.

### Reducing Time to First Byte (TTFB)
To optimize this parameter we moved all possible resources to the CDN, mainly everything that does not depend on database lookup.

### Lazy-loading
All the elements that are not necessary at the beginning, will be loaded as needed, in the case of images we generate a placeholder with very low resolution that will be replaced once the image has loaded.

### Image Optimization
During the build process, all images are converted to webp format, compressed and responsive versions are generated using the appropriate resolution for each screen resolution

### Reducing bundle size
Reducing the number of modules used in our page, looking for lighter alternatives or creating our own implementations with the resources we need

## A/B Testing

During the user's life, from the moment they enter the landing page until they end up on our waiting list, we were looking to optimize the registration flow so that a higher percentage of users would end up on our waiting list.

To do this, there are two elements on our page that should be analyzed:

- Does the landing page attract users' attention and provide them with enough information and confidence to want to learn more?
- Is the registration process simple enough so that there is no friction and users abandon?

To perform A/B testing it is important to keep in mind that its usefulness will be greater when the volume of visits is higher, it will be useless to make experiments if only a few users go through the funnel

# The Full Story

Zandbeek is a family-owned enterprise that places award-winning creativity at the center of its operations. Their forte lies in identifying, narrating, and linking brand stories that distinguish them from the competition. 

Collaborating with the [Studio Vi](https://viamsterdam.com/) team, Zandbeek enlisted our expertise to develop a new website that aligned with their fresh corporate identity. Our aim was to deliver an easy-to-use, welcoming interface with cutting-edge user experience (UX) features.

## Frontend

### Horizontal Scroll

The key feature of this page's design is the horizontal scroll, which directs the user's attention towards the project stories that Zandbeek wants to showcase. To achieve this, we utilized Locomotive Scroll instead of the default browser scroll. 

This provides us with greater control over the scroll's performance across all browsers, including the ability to program smooth scrolling, change the position of elements, and create parallax effects by adjusting the friction of individual elements.

### Smooth Scrolling
We implemented smooth scrolling across all pages, creating a seamless and polished user experience. This was further enhanced by input animations that appear when elements come into view. Together, these features create a more enjoyable browsing experience for the user, while also enabling lazy loading of elements that are not yet on the screen.

### Clean Transitions

We wanted to create a seamless transition for users as they navigate between projects. To achieve this, we used the main project image as a connecting element. When entering a project, we made the last frame of the main page and the first frame of the project page the same full-screen image. 

This approach creates a fluid, continuous experience for the user, even though there is a complete change in the underlying page structure. The result is a smooth and uninterrupted browsing experience that enhances the user's engagement with the content.
